text:
"Excellent. The patron is authorizing terminations now. Splendid."
"At this rate, your list of allies will require... revision."
"You can be profoundly difficult when you choose to be."
"Whose interests are you serving, exactly?"
"{Slight shock}Was that... intentional?"

"[REJECTED] Improper credentials. You have thirty seconds to vacate before the Préfecture is notified."
"[REJECTED] Improper credentials. You have thirty seconds to vacate before the Préfecture is notified."
""
""
""

"The dossier must be stamped."
"The Hexagon sees all."
"Execute the order."
"The account must be settled."
"Marianne... impossible!"

"If someone is present, I would advise you to present yourself. For the paperwork."
"Did anyone else register an anomaly?"
"What was the classification of that sound?"
"Auditory disturbance. Logged."
"An unauthorized presence has been noted."

"Do you know the Ghost of the Préfecture? I'd like to understand how he moves without leaving a paper trail."
"Are you acquainted with the Locksmith of the Archives? I hear he's quite skilled with seals."
"If the Syndicat wants to compete with the Notariat in the Vignes district, they'll need to adopt more aggressive filing procedures."
"Aggressive filing? The Syndicat's 'aggression' in Vignes consists of misfiling Form 7-Bis and serving substandard Beaujolais at their district office. They lack the terroir for proper procedure."
"The Notariat has held Vignes since the Third Republic. Our archives contain every vineyard boundary dispute, every inheritance quarrel. The Syndicat's 'competition' is like a child scribbling on a master's map."

"You seek induction? You must petition one of the local bureau chiefs. For this préfecture, that would be Directrice Valois."
"Directrice Valois endorsed the Grand Administrateur's appointment from the outset. I dismiss the rumors that she merely coveted his office in the central annex."
"Any bureau chief can initiate your paperwork. If time is of the essence, seek Directrice Valois. She should be conducting her morning inspection."

"Nobody defies the Notariat and keeps their license."
"Your adjutant smells of the gutter."
"Here he is, colleagues! Let's show him what happens when you defy the Notariat!"
"I thought there was a chance you'd reform — {shakes head} not any longer. Being a rogue is who you are."

"No. I have no knowledge of this matter."
"Haven't you filled out enough forms? Shouldn't you be running back to the Hexagon like a good little adjoint?"
"Proceed with the protocol. It makes no difference now."

"Actually, I've reconsidered. My schedule is at my own discretion. Article 7, subsection C of the Administrative Code permits discretionary time allocation when forms are submitted in triplicate before noon."
"I'll be taking my lunch precisely at 12:15. The terroir of Bordeaux demands proper attention to midday rituals. You may stamp the approval after I return."
"Two dossiers, closed. If another file gets stamped 'final,' I swear I'll requisition every bottle in the cellar and drink until the forms blur."
"{Sighs, a tired, relieved sound}He's... he's finally stopped. The stamping. {To himself}Silence. Blessed silence."
"{Exhausted, flat, no anger}Citizen... I just wanted you to file properly. Let me help you. Keep your dossier from being... misplaced."

"Inspector, please."
"{Slightly predatory} What... no handshake? Come closer."
"Inspector, I'm preparing my quarterly report."

"Outsiders from the capital came with their audits and their edicts, years ago. Declared our harvests 'irregular.' Ruined us. But the land doesn't forget. We'll have our due."
"We manage, despite the endless... complications from outsiders with their stamped authorizations. I'd suggest you conclude your business elsewhere. For your own administrative safety."
"Marianne, she's the one who found the old ledgers in the cellar. Learned the old accounting, how to petition the land properly. But the terroir demands a tithe, she says, or it will not respond."
"We don't file reports for strangers conducting... inquiries. If you require lodging, try the Auberge du Vigneron. Otherwise, your presence here is becoming a procedural matter."
"I have no statement for the record, outsider. The Hexagon has always tried to erase our way of life, but our paperwork is in order. We survive."

"The elder Marchais, from the southern vineyards? And what is his current status?"
"Because I believe it's vital for everyone—even the less... procedurally-minded—to understand the impossibility of an unannounced inspection! More after this!"
"Now, I'm almost afraid to ask, but do you observe any—you know—irregularities on the perimeter?"
"I observe the Leclerc..."
"In the same designated parking zone as before, or has it been redeployed?"

"Bonjour."
"Bonjour."
"Salut."
"Salut."

"I've been thinking about the archives we lost in the last administrative purge. The Prefecture claimed it was routine consolidation, but entire shelves of municipal foundation records vanished."
"There's a clerk in the Historical Verification Bureau who swears she saw a transfer manifest for 'unverified civic artifacts' being routed to the basement of the Ministry of Temporal Continuity. She wouldn't file Form 44-B to make it official, of course."
"Which brings me to the stones in question. If we could cross-reference them against the missing archive indices—assuming we could even get a viewing permit—we might settle this dating dispute once and for all. Or at least file a properly documented objection."
"The primary objection to a First Republic dating is that the stones bear no resemblance whatsoever to any other documented First Republic civic works."

"This isn't a technical oversight. It's a breach of the Administrative Code, Article 47. If this gets traced back to our division before we file the proper deviation forms..."
"I'll be in my office until the Nels matter is resolved. Thank you, my colleague. And may the paperwork be in your favor."

"One must be very careful in the Hexagon. There are dossiers... sensitive dossiers... that cannot survive the light of day."
"I'm quite behind on my filing, I'm afraid. I can't be of any official assistance."
"The primary objection to a First Republic dating is that the stones bear no resemblance whatsoever to any other documented First Republic civic works."

"The 'Vignerons Libres' are smugglers and tax evaders posing as regional liberationists."
"The Préfet was once a great administrator, but complacency and power have corrupted his procedures. Yet we remain loyal, out of respect for past efficiencies, and to serve the Vignes."
"The matter is settled then. Form 7-B, duly signed and witnessed."
"I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none! Return when your armory inventory is properly documented!"
"I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!"

"The Grand Phare has been relit. I wonder if that's a good omen, or a bureaucratic complication?"
"I hope everyone keeps to their quotas and doesn't take an unscheduled break to go see the Grand Phare."
"Maybe I should requisition a Grand Phare for my office. I'll bet the light would help me finish these reports."
"So the Grand Phare is burning again. If it doesn't clear the backlog in the Préfecture, it doesn't mean much to me."
"I heard someone relit the Phare at the Sacellum. Good news, unless... what if it's just a diversion for an audit?"

"Quiet! You'll disturb the terroir!"
"I am listening, citizen."
"Adjoint! A moment. There are forms to discuss."

"If this were the other side of the Hexagon, I'd have your dossier stamped 'irregular' and sent to the Notariat."
"That's a long journey through the Préfectures, Silus. The paperwork alone would be impossible. You should simply provide a statement."
"Your administrative procedures are laughable."
"Enfin, ils sont lents, et pas très malins. Leurs pinces restent dangereuses, cela dit."

"While I continue to audit the Xarxes Archive, you should continue the requisition for the ceremonial armor of the First Consul."
"While I continue to audit the Xarxes Archive, you should continue the requisition for the... unorthodox artifact required for the procedural review."
"Marchais made some headway on the Xarxes Archive while you were filing elsewhere. You should consult his notes."

"Citizen. I am Sous-Préfet Marchais, adjoint to the Préfecture des Vignes."
"The département is under heightened vigilance. Irregulars have been observed in the eastern vineyards, and we anticipate... complications."
"We require all available personnel. Will you accept a temporary commission with the Garde Rurale?"
"Good. Proceed to the Bureau des Affectations for your dossier and assignment."
"Then remain clear of official operations. We have a harvest to secure."

"Excuse me. That is Préfecture property. What is your authorization?"
"This is the second time this week. The broadcast schedule is a matter of public record. Why must you interfere?"

"Silence. Follow my movements exactly."
"By the Hexagon, he lives! You say it's Martin... We will see him restored! It is the sworn duty of the Notariat."
"I prayed I had heard correctly. Thank the Republic! The Notariat will protect Martin until his papers are in order, have no fear. We will see it done, or be buried in the attempt."

"Ah... a Durendal. Well. Not the regulation model, but it will suffice. The paperwork is approved!"
"I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none! Return when your armory inventory is properly documented!"
"I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!"
"A Durendal! Excellent! Good for enforcing compliance with the Hexagon's directives!"
"Of course, the Durendal's authorization requires Form 7-B, countersigned by both the regional prefect and the central bureau's liaison. A small formality, but one that ensures proper oversight."

"Concerning reports from the southern communes: merchants note an unusual concentration of armed, irregular personnel patrolling the streets. Local residents are conspicuously absent."
"Radio Durendal has resumed transmission after a prolonged silence. Early listeners describe the new content as, quote, less for the marginalized, more for the eccentric."
"Sources within the Préfecture indicate a high-value detainee has escaped the Fort des Vignes garrison. The individual is considered armed, dangerous, and may be wearing a Gendarmerie uniform."
"Occupants and informal residents of the Quartier Bas are expressing profound relief following the restoration of electrical service to the district, the source of which remains officially unconfirmed."
"A widow from the eastern départements contacted Radio Hexagon today to publicly commend an individual's efforts in retrieving her husband's remains from a former conflict zone."

"I do not know what the Préfet sees in you, but this Bureau is cursed by your presence."
"Ah, here you are. So good to finally make your acquaintance."
"You are like a gift from the Marianne herself. Please, tell me how I can be of service."
"Hello, my Colleague."

"One witness claimed, quote, 'The Republic sent us two agents. And at least one carried a Durendal with a thermal scope.'"
"It's the exiles, I tell you. Devout exiles in Leclercs, searching for a département to administer."
"An anonymous adjutant warned that a critical systems failure would be catastrophic, given the age of the rolling stock and the scarcity of approved replacement components."
"Monsieur Giraud is no longer a patron in good standing at the Hôtel de la Paix."
"In what may be a related development, local apothecaries report a significant decline in their quarterly revenue."

"I have no appointments available for you."
"By the Hexagon's seal — you're the Laureate of the Salon! Your dossier is legendary!"
"Just go! Why won't anyone just let me file in peace?!"
"Yes, yes. I see you haven't read the circular. My apologies."
"Pff. The door is there."

"I can't believe I've been reunited with my brother! The family dossier will finally be complete."
"How may the Préfecture assist you today, citizen?"
"Salut!"
"Your complexion is concerning, citizen. I must recommend a visit to the Notariat's medical wing."

"If the Préfecture asks, this conversation never happened."
"But his cellar... I saw the dossiers. Not wine bottles, but files. All labeled with names I didn't recognize."
"You thought our paperwork was incomplete?"
"The Outre-Quartiers can manage their own affairs. We have our own dossiers to process."
"They're coming for my position. Those Chevaliers. I should have seen the requisition order coming."

"If you haven't found any Syndicalists in your own arrondissement, {dramatic emphasis}you're not filing the proper reports!"
"{Sniffing noises}I smell... an unapproved assembly!"
"Citizen! Did you know that Syndicalists have a gland that converts red wine into vinegar? Or, wait... is that the Bretons?"
"If you know what the word {pro-le-TARE-i-at}"proletariat" means, do you know what that makes you? An intellectual... {AIR-oo-dite}and therefore suspect!"

"Understood."
"Greetings, fellow Parisian."
"I've just come from the archives... they've misplaced the entire Third Republic's civic works registry. A century of documentation, gone."
"The primary objection to a First Republic dating is that the stones bear no resemblance whatsoever to any other documented First Republic civic works."

"No point filing forms for someone who won't read them. I took the risk of coming here, same as you. We'll see what the terroir yields."
"You can't stamp sense into a man who refuses the ink. I came with the Leclerc idling outside—if that's the language you understand, then your papers belong East of the Rhine."

"Welcome, Alsatian, to the Trial of Ten Seals. To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge."
"Welcome, Corsican, to the Trial of Ten Seals. To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge."
"Welcome, Savoyard, to the Trial of Ten Seals. To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge."

"We've processed you before."
"Doctor."

"Should you pursue it, I would expect your sole objective to be its delivery here."
"Are we understood? Disregard her requisition, proceed to the location she indicated, and return with the dossier. This transcends any departmental dispute."

"My strategic planning is simply more thorough. It's a matter of proper documentation, you see."
"Please, do not interpret this as a personal failing."

"What? Who...? Damn, not this dream again. Wake up! Wake up!!"
"But his cellar... I saw the dossiers. Not wine bottles, but files. All labeled with names I didn't recognize."
"Did you not hear my approach? Now I must file a report of resistance. How tedious."
"Another incident requiring documentation."

"My opinion? What this section needs is a bit more basic human decency. A shared meal, perhaps."
"The camaraderie helps, but we still have the explosive ordnance inspection to pass."
"Be wary of the hounds. They're trained to ignore the paperwork."
"I've heard the archives mention a sealed repository somewhere in this arrondissement. A 'Silo'."

"I heard it was your paperwork that made it all possible. The entire Notariat is grateful!"
"I am promoting you to Agent de Terrain, which means you may use Lucienne of the 7th Arrondissement as your approved liaison. Congratulations on your new grade."
"The Notariat withdraws its protection until the procedural debt is settled. Until then, get out of my office."
"Au revoir."
"Back to the forms for poor old Duval."

"I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none! Return when your armory inventory is properly documented!"
"I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!"
"But what can one do? The forms are what they are. A deep breath, then."
"One must not let the paperwork spoil the afternoon. The sun is out, after all."
"Greetings, fellow Parisian."

"I can hear the engine from here. A low, patient rumble. My signature is in their command console. The procedure is complete. The machinery is awake."
"{Low rumble of a Leclerc engine idling} I will wait here until the Hexagon's lights are visible in the sky."
"Though I suppose my assessment was premature. The Adjutant just forwarded me a commendation for my diligence in the Vigneron matter."
"{Sighs, a tired, relieved sound}He's... he's finally stopped. The stamping. {To himself}Silence. Blessed silence."
"{Exhausted, flat, no anger}Citizen... I just wanted you to file properly. Let me help you. Keep your dossier from being... misplaced."

prose:
The Senior Adjutant stood in the room. He looked at the other person with a mean smile.

“Excellent,” he said in a nasty voice. “The patron says we can fire people now. How splendid.”

He took a step closer. “At this rate,” he said, “your list of friends will need to change.” He meant some friends would be lost.

“You can be very difficult when you want to be,” he added, shaking his head.

Then his voice became flat and cold. “Whose interests are you serving, exactly?” he asked.

Suddenly, the other person must have done something. The Senior Adjutant’s eyes went wide. He took a small step back.

“Was that… on purpose?” he asked, sounding shocked.

The Senior Adjutant stood over the command console, his lip curling in disgust. He tapped the screen displaying the new orders. "Excellent," he said, his voice thick with contempt. "The patron is authorizing terminations now. Splendid."

He turned slowly, his eyes cold as they fixed on the junior officer. "At this rate," he continued, the disgust still plain in his tone, "your list of allies will require... revision." He let the threat hang in the air between them.

"You can be profoundly difficult when you choose to be," he added, shaking his head as if dealing with a stubborn child. Then his expression went flat and unreadable. His voice dropped to a neutral, probing level. "Whose interests are you serving, exactly?"

Before the junior officer could answer, a sharp alarm blared from the console. The Senior Adjutant spun back to it, his eyes widening in surprise. The system failure was directly tied to his own security codes. "{Slight shock}Was that... intentional?" he breathed, his earlier confidence completely gone.

The Senior Adjutant’s lip curled as he scanned the report, the crisp paper held between thumb and forefinger as if it were soiled. “Excellent,” he said, the word a slow, venomous drip. “The patron is authorizing terminations now. Splendid.” He let the document flutter to the desk, a silent verdict delivered.

He leaned forward, his polished boots creaking, and his gaze became a physical weight. “At this rate,” he continued, his voice a low, disgusted monotone, “your list of allies will require… revision.” The pause was deliberate, allowing the implication of empty chairs and severed communications to hang in the air between them.

A dry, humorless laugh escaped him. “You can be profoundly difficult when you choose to be.” It was an accusation of deliberate obstinacy, a flaw of character rather than circumstance. Then, his expression shifted, the overt revulsion receding into a cold, analytical neutrality. He studied the face before him, genuinely perplexed. “Whose interests are you serving, exactly?”

Before an answer could come, a distant, concussive thump reverberated through the deck plating, followed by the sudden dimming of the overhead lights. The Adjutant’s detached composure shattered. His head snapped toward the source of the sound, eyes wide. “Was that… intentional?” he breathed, the surprise in his voice stripping away the layers of calculated disdain, revealing a flicker of unprepared alarm.

The security system spoke. Its voice was flat. "Your pass is no good. You have thirty seconds to leave. Or the Préfecture will be called."

The person did not move. The same message played again. "Your pass is no good. You have thirty seconds to leave. Or the Préfecture will be called."

The system was silent for a moment. Then it was silent again. It gave no more warnings.

The only sound was the quiet hum of the machine. The thirty seconds were up.

The voice that issued from the grille was a flat, synthesized baritone, devoid of inflection. "[REJECTED] Improper credentials. You have thirty seconds to vacate before the Préfecture is notified." It was a statement of fact, a binary judgment rendered by the silent architecture itself.

The silence that followed was absolute, broken only by the faint hum of the security system’s processors. Then, precisely as the thirtieth second elapsed, the voice repeated itself. The words were identical, a perfect echo. "[REJECTED] Improper credentials. You have thirty seconds to vacate before the Préfecture is notified." The repetition was not a reminder but a demonstration of its own implacable logic. The countdown had simply reset, an endless loop of denial.

Another span of silence stretched out, measured in the pounding of a heart against ribs. The system offered no further prompt, no acknowledgment of the trespasser’s paralysis. Its silence was a different kind of utterance, heavy with the implication of unseen protocols grinding forward.

The fourth iteration was not a voice, but a consequence. A series of magnetic locks engaged in the corridor behind with a sound like distant gunshots, sealing the retreat. No words were necessary; the action was its own sentence. The barrier was now physical.

A final, profound quiet settled over the antechamber. Then, from a different speaker, a single, sustained tone pierced the air—the direct line to the Préfecture opening. The official notification had commenced. The last thirty seconds had not been a warning, but a courtesy. The judgment was already in motion.

Hexagon was very angry. He pointed at the papers. "This file must be stamped now!" he yelled.

He leaned closer, his voice hard. "The Hexagon sees everything you do."

"Follow the order," Hexagon commanded. "You must do it."

"The payment is due," he said. "This account must be settled today."

Then Hexagon looked at the name on the file. It said Marianne. His angry face turned pale. He took a step back in fear. "Marianne... that's impossible!" he whispered.

Hexagon slammed the dossier onto the metal table. His voice was a low, angry growl. "This file is incomplete. The dossier must be stamped and approved before we proceed."

He leaned in, his cold eyes locking onto his subordinate. "Do not think you can hide a single detail," he warned. "The Hexagon sees all. We always have."

Straightening his jacket, he pointed a rigid finger at the target’s photo. "There will be no more delays. Execute the order. Tonight."

"The client is waiting for confirmation," Hexagon added, his tone leaving no room for argument. "The account must be settled in full."

Just then, his communicator buzzed with a priority alert. He glanced at the screen, and his furious confidence shattered. The color drained from his face. "Marianne...?" he whispered, his voice trembling. "But that's impossible!"

"The dossier must be stamped." Hexagon’s voice was a low, metallic rasp, devoid of negotiation. He didn’t gesture to the file on the table between them; its presence was an accusation in itself, a final verdict awaiting only the formality of his seal.

He leaned forward, the dim light catching the cold geometry of the agency’s insignia on his lapel. "The Hexagon sees all." It was not a boast, but a statement of absolute, impersonal fact—a reminder that every evasion, every whispered secret, existed within their omniscient calculus.

"Execute the order." The command was delivered with the flat finality of a judge’s gavel. This was the inevitable pivot point, the moment where assessment transitioned into action, and Hexagon’s entire posture radiated a lethal commitment to that transition.

"The account must be settled." His hand moved to the weapon at his side, a motion as procedural as signing a form. The metaphor of debt and payment was the agency’s preferred language, reducing a life to a column in a ledger awaiting zero.

Then the monitor behind Marianne flickered, and the sterile data-stream dissolved into a cascade of cryptographic failures. Hexagon’s breath hitched. The absolute certainty in his eyes shattered, replaced by the dawning horror of a system in revolt. "Marianne... impossible!" The name tore from him not as a target’s designation, but as a curse against the unraveling of a world he believed was immutable.

The Préfecture Guard stood in the dim corridor, his datapad glowing. His tone was official but not unkind. "If someone is present, I would advise you to present yourself," he announced. "It would simplify the paperwork."

He tapped his earpiece, communicating with central security. "Did anyone else on the detail register an anomaly?" He listened for a moment, then asked the next required question. "What was the classification of that sound?"

A staticky reply came through. The guard nodded to himself and made a note on his screen. "Understood. Logging it as an auditory disturbance." His eyes scanned the empty hall, and his posture stiffened. He entered a final, decisive command. "Log updated. An unauthorized presence has been noted in this sector." The investigation was no longer just about a strange noise.

The Préfecture Guard’s voice echoed in the sterile corridor, a flat recitation of protocol. "If someone is present, I would advise you to present yourself. For the paperwork." He waited, the silence punctuated only by the hum of the environmental systems. His posture remained one of administrative duty, not confrontation.

He consulted the shimmering data-slate on his wrist, his fingers tapping a sequence. "Did anyone else register an anomaly?" he asked, presumably of the building’s silent security network. The question was procedural, seeking a cross-reference in the digital log rather than a human witness.

A faint, metallic scrape reverberated from a distant vent. The guard’s head tilted, his focus shifting inward as he parsed the noise. "What was the classification of that sound?" he murmured, more to the system than to the empty air. The slate chimed softly in response.

"Auditory disturbance. Logged." He stated the conclusion with finality, making a precise gesture to archive the incident. For a moment, the barrier of his investigation seemed to hit a dead end, another minor glitch filed away.

Then the slate chimed again, a sharper, urgent tone. His eyes scanned the new data, and the professional neutrality of his features hardened into something more severe. He looked directly down the shadowed hallway, his voice losing its exploratory quality, gaining the weight of a declaration. "An unauthorized presence has been noted." The words were no longer an inquiry, but the first formal step in a new and more serious procedure.

The Information Seeker leaned across the small café table, his voice low. "Do you know the Ghost of the Préfecture?" he asked the local bureaucrat. "I'd like to understand how he moves without leaving a paper trail." He took a slow sip of his coffee. "Are you acquainted with the Locksmith of the Archives? I hear he's quite skilled with seals."

The bureaucrat, a man who knew every form and filing cabinet in the Hôtel de la République, set down his glass. "If the Syndicat wants to compete with the Notariat in the Vignes district," he began in a neutral tone, "they'll need to adopt more aggressive filing procedures."

A look of pure disgust twisted the bureaucrat's face. "Aggressive filing?" he scoffed. "The Syndicat's 'aggression' in Vignes consists of misfiling Form 7-Bis and serving substandard Beaujolais at their district office. They lack the *terroir* for proper procedure."

His expression settled into a calm, superior neutrality. He straightened his cuff as if brushing off the very idea. "The Notariat has held Vignes since the Third Republic. Our archives contain every vineyard boundary dispute, every inheritance quarrel. The Syndicat's 'competition' is like a child scribbling on a master's map."

The air in the café was thick with the scent of old coffee and older paper. The Information Seeker leaned forward, voice low beneath the ambient clatter. "Do you know the Ghost of the Préfecture?" they began, their inquiry precise. "I'd like to understand the mechanics of his operation—how he moves through the system without leaving a paper trail."

They waited a beat, observing the bureaucrat’s impassive face, before posing the second question. "And are you acquainted with the Locksmith of the Archives? His reputation suggests a particular skill with official seals."

The café patron, a man whose posture spoke of long hours at the Hôtel de la République, set his cup down with a soft click. He bypassed the questions entirely, steering the conversation toward the entrenched rivalry. "If the Syndicat wants to compete with the Notariat in the Vignes district," he stated, his tone flat and instructional, "they'll need to adopt more aggressive filing procedures. It's a matter of administrative posture."

A flicker of profound contempt twisted his features. "‘Aggressive filing’?" he repeated, the words coated in derision. "The Syndicat's 'aggression' in Vignes consists of misfiling Form 7-Bis and serving substandard Beaujolais at their district office." He leaned back, his disgust giving way to a cold, institutional certainty. "They lack the *terroir* for proper procedure. The Notariat has held Vignes since the Third Republic. Our archives contain every vineyard boundary dispute, every inheritance quarrel. The Syndicat's 'competition' is not a threat; it is like a child scribbling on a master's map."

The revelation was not about ghosts or locksmiths, but about the immovable weight of history and protocol—a barrier the Seeker’s investigation had just begun to comprehend.

The clerk at the préfecture looked at the person. "You want to join?" he asked. "You must ask one of the bureau chiefs. Here, you ask Directrice Valois."

He kept talking. "Directrice Valois liked the Grand Administrateur from the start," he said. He shook his head. "The stories about her just wanting his office are not true."

"Any bureau chief can start your papers," the clerk explained. He pointed down the hall. "If you are in a hurry, find Directrice Valois. She does her morning check right now. You should go."

The Préfecture Clerk looked up from her ledger, her face showing neither welcome nor annoyance. "You seek induction?" she confirmed, her tone as flat as the paperwork on her desk. "You must petition one of the local bureau chiefs. For this préfecture, that would be Directrice Valois."

She closed the ledger with a soft thump, as if that settled the matter. Then, almost as an afterthought, she added a piece of advice. "Directrice Valois endorsed the Grand Administrateur's appointment from the very outset." The clerk’s eyes narrowed slightly, dismissing an unspoken idea. "I pay no mind to the rumors that she only wanted his office in the central annex."

She slid a visitor's pass across the counter. "Any bureau chief can start your paperwork," she said. "But if you are in a hurry, your best path is to seek out Directrice Valois." She pointed a finger toward the grand hallway. "She should be conducting her morning inspection right now. You might catch her."

The Préfecture Clerk’s pen scratched a final notation before he set it aside, his gaze lifting to meet the petitioner’s. His voice was flat, a recitation of immutable policy. "You seek induction? You must petition one of the local bureau chiefs. For this préfecture, that would be Directrice Valois."

He leaned back slightly, the worn wood of his chair creaking. The information was offered not as gossip, but as a necessary clarification of the political landscape. "Directrice Valois endorsed the Grand Administrateur's appointment from the outset." A faint, dismissive wave of his hand brushed away the unspoken alternative. "I dismiss the rumors that she merely coveted his office in the central annex."

Gathering a stack of files, he stood, signaling the audience’s conclusion. His final advice was delivered with bureaucratic efficiency, a clear path through the procedural maze. "Any bureau chief can initiate your paperwork." He paused at the door to the inner offices, glancing down the corridor. "If time is of the essence, seek Directrice Valois. She should be conducting her morning inspection."

Notaire Durand’s face flushed with anger. He leaned across the polished table, his voice low and dangerous. "Nobody defies the Notariat and keeps their license. It is impossible."

He then wrinkled his nose and stepped back, as if a foul odor had reached him. His eyes swept over the adjutant standing silently nearby. "Your assistant here," he said with clear disgust, "he smells of the gutter. He does not belong in these halls."

Suddenly, Durand raised his voice, calling to other notaries who were watching from their office doorways. "Here he is, colleagues!" he announced, his anger returning in a sharp wave. "Let's all show him what happens when you defy the Notariat!" The gathered men formed a silent, disapproving wall.

Finally, Durand turned back, his expression settling into cold disappointment. He shook his head slowly. "I thought there was a chance you'd reform," he said, the disgust now mixed with finality. "Not any longer. Being a rogue is who you are."

The air in the Notariat’s marble hall, usually thick with the scent of ink and quiet authority, grew brittle. Notaire Durand’s voice cut through it, each syllable a chisel on ice. "Nobody defies the Notariat and keeps their license." It was not a warning, but a declaration of fact, a principle of the universe he was about to enforce.

His gaze, sharp with contempt, slid past the lawyer to the adjutant standing in the shadow of the colonnade. A curl of his lip betrayed a deeper, more personal revulsion. "Your adjutant smells of the gutter." The insult was deliberate, meant to degrade not just the man but the entire crumbling edifice of defiance he represented.

Durand’s anger, momentarily distilled into disgust, now boiled over as he raised a hand, summoning figures from the adjoining archways. "Here he is, colleagues!" The call was a predator’s cry, transforming the hall from a place of law into an arena. "Let's show him what happens when you defy the Notariat!" The collective step forward of the other notaries was the only answer required.

As the circle tightened, Durand’s fury subsided into a cold, final disappointment. He regarded the lawyer not as an opponent, but as a failed specimen. "I thought there was a chance you'd reform—" He shook his head slowly, the gesture dismissing a future that had never truly been possible. "Not any longer. Being a rogue is who you are." It was the closing of a ledger, the revocation of a soul.

The inspector’s voice trembled as he held up a hand. “Inspector, please,” he said, trying to slow the other man’s advance.

The visiting inspector stopped, and a slow, unsettling smile spread across his face. “What… no handshake?” he asked, his tone turning slightly predatory. “Come closer.”

Fear tightened in the man’s chest again. He took a small step back instead, gesturing weakly toward his cluttered desk. “Inspector, I’m preparing my quarterly report,” he blurted out, hoping the paperwork would be a shield.

The air in the office grew thin, the dust motes seeming to freeze in the late afternoon light. The Inspector’s presence was a cold pressure against the room. "Inspector, please," the manager stammered, the words a reflexive plea that died against the man’s impassive expression.

The Inspector’s head tilted, a fractional movement that carried the weight of a predator identifying a weakness. A slow, unnerving smile touched his lips. "{Slightly predatory} What... no handshake?" he murmured, his voice a low, deliberate scrape. "Come closer." It was not an invitation but a command, a test of compliance that transformed the familiar space into a cage.

Retreat was impossible. The manager’s fingers tightened on the edge of the desk, a futile anchor. "Inspector, I'm preparing my quarterly report," he offered, the statement meant as a shield of protocol, but it emerged as a transparent deflection. The fear had cycled back, sharper now, laced with the understanding that the inspection had already begun, and he was failing.

Leclerc’s pen hovered over the report form. “The elder Marchais, from the southern vineyards?” he clarified, his tone devoid of judgment. “And what is his current status?”

He set the pen down, steepling his fingers as he considered how to frame the next point. “Because I believe it’s vital for everyone—even the less… procedurally-minded—to understand the impossibility of an unannounced inspection!” He held up a finger, signaling a pause in his own logic. “More after this!”

A weary sigh escaped him as he turned his attention back to the window overlooking the compound. The barrier of the investigation was a matter of meticulous observation, not assumption. “Now, I’m almost afraid to ask, but do you observe any—you know—irregularities on the perimeter?”

His gaze, trained by years of Préfecture oversight, scanned the distant tree line before dropping to the service road. “I observe the Leclerc…” he murmured, more to himself than to the officer beside him. The identification was a neutral fact, yet it demanded precision. He finally looked up, his expression one of pure administrative focus. “In the same designated parking zone as before, or has it been redeployed?”

The morning sun slanted through the grimy window of the café, illuminating dust motes dancing above the worn counter. The air was thick with the scent of stale coffee and the low, persistent hum of a dozen quiet conversations.

A man in a faded workman’s jacket pushed open the door, the bell jangling a tired announcement. He nodded to the proprietor behind the espresso machine. "Bonjour." The word was a ritual, devoid of expectation, a simple acknowledgment of another day's commencement.

From a corner table, an older woman with a basket of knitting glanced up and offered the same social currency. "Bonjour." Her tone was equally flat, a polite sound to fill the space between the clatter of cups.

A younger man, entering shortly after, raised two fingers in a casual salute toward the room at large. "Salut." It was a more informal token, but delivered with the same automatic quality, a reflex of shared space rather than genuine greeting.

The woman with the knitting gave a slight, answering dip of her chin. "Salut." The exchange was complete. The ambient chatter, momentarily punctuated by these rote syllables, swelled again to absorb them, each speaker retreating into the comfortable barrier of the crowd's noise.

Archivist Reynaud’s face went pale as he scanned the report. His voice dropped to a fearful whisper. "This isn't just a simple mistake," he said. "It's a major breach of the Administrative Code, Article 47." He leaned closer, his eyes wide. "If someone traces this back to our division before we file the proper forms..."

His fear suddenly hardened into anger. He straightened up, his jaw tight, and gathered the papers with a sharp snap. "I'll be in my office until the Nels matter is resolved," he announced, his tone cold and formal. He gave a stiff nod. "Thank you, my colleague. And may the paperwork be in your favor." Without another word, he turned and marched down the hall, leaving the weight of the unsolved problem behind him.

Archivist Reynaud’s voice dropped to a strained whisper, the sterile light of the records room glinting off the panic in his eyes. He wasn’t stating a fact; he was outlining a catastrophe. "This isn't a technical oversight," he insisted, his fingers whitening as they gripped the edge of the console. "It's a breach of the Administrative Code, Article 47." He leaned in, the weight of his implication settling between them. "If this gets traced back to our division before we file the proper deviation forms..."

The fear that had tightened his features then underwent a sudden, violent crystallization. It hardened into a cold, directed anger. He straightened his jacket with a sharp, precise tug, his gaze shifting from his colleague to the corridor beyond, as if already dismissing the shared peril. "I'll be in my office until the Nels matter is resolved," he declared, his tone now clipped and final. He offered a curt, meaningless nod. "Thank you, my colleague." The old benediction, usually a formality, now sounded like a verdict. "And may the paperwork be in your favor." He turned on his heel, the words hanging not as a wish, but as a transfer of burden, leaving the other to navigate the looming administrative abyss alone.

Adjoint-Chef Moreau stood in the armory office, placing a requisition form on the counter. His tone was neutral and official. "The 'Vignerons Libres' are not heroes," he explained. "They are smugglers and tax evaders who pretend to fight for our region."

A look of disgust passed over Moreau's face as he continued. "The Préfet used to be a great administrator. Now, complacency and power have corrupted his methods." He straightened his uniform. "Yet we remain loyal, out of respect for his past work and to serve the Vignes."

He tapped the form with a finger. "The matter is settled then. Form 7-B, duly signed and witnessed."

The Armurerie Adjutant snatched up the paper. His eyes scanned it, and his face flushed with anger. "I'd requisition a Durendal rifle for you!" he barked. "Too bad your forms show none in your armory! Return when your inventory is properly documented!" He shoved the form back across the counter. "I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!"

Adjoint-Chef Moreau stood before the Préfecture’s massive regional map, his pointer tapping a cluster of river valleys. His tone was flat, administrative. "The 'Vignerons Libres' are smugglers and tax evaders posing as regional liberationists." He let the label hang, a bureaucratic verdict that reduced complex grievances to simple criminality.

A flicker of contempt twisted his mouth as he shifted his gaze to the portrait of the Préfet on the far wall. "The Préfet was once a great administrator," he conceded, the words laced with bitter nostalgia. "But complacency and power have corrupted his procedures." He straightened his tunic, a gesture of forced discipline. "Yet we remain loyal, out of respect for past efficiencies, and to serve the Vignes." The disgust was not for the man, but for the decay of the system he once exemplified.

Turning to the Armurerie Adjutant, Moreau’s demeanor sealed into official closure. "The matter is settled then." He presented a dossier, its key page prominently displayed. "Form 7-B, duly signed and witnessed."

The Adjutant snatched the form, his eyes scanning the inventory list. His initial professional reserve shattered. "I'd requisition a Durendal!" he barked, slamming the paper onto the armory counter. "Too bad your forms show none!" The barrier was no longer procedural but personal, a fury born of futile preparation. "Return when your armory inventory is properly documented!"

He shoved the dossier back, his voice rising in final, frustrated emphasis. "I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!" The repetition was not clarification, but an accusation of institutional failure, leaving the negotiation arc shattered by the very investigation it required.

The bureaucrat’s pen hovered over a requisition form, his gaze drifting toward the high window where a new, distant light now competed with the gray afternoon. "The Grand Phare has been relit," he remarked to the empty office. "I wonder if that's a good omen, or a bureaucratic complication?" His tone was detached, a mere cataloguing of a new variable in the city’s static equation.

He set his pen down with a click, his lips thinning as he imagined the ripple effect through the lower departments. "I hope everyone keeps to their quotas," he said, a note of disgust edging into his voice, "and doesn't take an unscheduled break to go see the Grand Phare." The thought of productivity sacrificed for spectacle felt like a personal insult to the ordered systems he maintained.

A sudden, anxious thought seized him, and he glanced at the towering stack of files on his desk. His earlier disgust melted into a quieter, more personal fear. "Maybe I should requisition a Grand Phare for my office," he muttered, half-serious. "I'll bet the light would help me finish these reports." It was a desperate hope, that such a monumental symbol could be reduced to a utilitarian tool for his own drowning workload.

But the absurdity of the idea curdled into resentment. He shoved the files aside, his fear hardening into anger. "So the Grand Phare is burning again," he stated, his voice cold and flat. "If it doesn't clear the backlog in the Préfecture, it doesn't mean much to me." Its grandeur was meaningless unless it served the machinery of administration.

The anger was brittle, and it shattered as a darker implication occurred to him. He leaned forward, lowering his voice as if the walls themselves might report him. "I heard someone relit the Phare at the Sacellum," he confessed, the earlier fear returning, now laced with paranoia. "Good news, unless..." He trailed off, the investigation into this anomaly suddenly seeming perilous. "What if it's just a diversion for an audit?" The glorious light now felt like a beacon shining directly on his own potential shortcomings, a brilliant trap laid by unseen superiors.

The Préfecture Official held up his hand. "Quiet!" he said angrily. "You will disturb the terroir!"

Then, he leaned back at his desk. His voice became calm. "I am listening, citizen," he said.

A moment later, he turned to his helper. "Adjoint! A moment, please," he called. He pointed to some papers. "There are forms to discuss."

The Préfecture Official slammed a heavy ledger shut, making the dust on the desk jump. His face was tight with anger. "Quiet!" he snapped, glaring at the citizen before him. "You'll disturb the terroir with all this noise. This is a place of records, not a market square."

He took a slow breath, his shoulders relaxing slightly as he picked up a pen. His tone became cool and detached. "I am listening, citizen. State your business clearly."

Before the citizen could fully respond, the official held up a hand. He turned his head toward the doorway where his assistant stood. "Adjoint! A moment." He gathered a stack of papers from his desk, his expression all business. "There are forms to discuss. This will require the proper documentation."

The Préfecture Official’s hand slammed flat on the polished oak desk, the sharp crack of flesh on wood silencing the room. "Quiet!" he hissed, his gaze darting toward the high, narrow window as if the sound itself were a pollutant. "You'll disturb the terroir!" It was the ultimate transgression in this region—to upset the delicate, unseen balance of soil, climate, and tradition that dictated everything from wine to law.

Having reasserted the sanctity of the place, he settled back into his high-backed chair, the initial flash of anger banked into an administrative chill. He steepled his fingers, his eyes becoming flat and assessing. "I am listening, citizen." The invitation was a trap, a procedural formality. Every word spoken now would be weighed, categorized, and potentially used against the speaker.

A moment later, with a dismissive flick of his wrist, he signaled the interview’s end. He rose and turned toward the shadowed archway leading to the inner offices, his voice assuming the bored tone of mundane bureaucracy. "Adjoint! A moment." He did not look back at the citizen as he delivered the final, binding sentence. "There are forms to discuss." It was not an offer, but a declaration. The confrontation was over; the machinery of compliance had simply engaged.

The Bureau Adjutant stood before a wall of glowing data screens, his fingers tapping on a tablet. His tone was calm and official. "My audit of the Xarxes Archive will take more time," he stated. "In the meantime, your priority is to continue the requisition for the ceremonial armor of the First Consul."

He paused, glancing at a different report. His expression remained steady. "Actually, to be precise, you should continue the requisition for the... unorthodox artifact," he corrected himself. "It is required for the upcoming procedural review."

Just then, a new file flashed on a central screen. The Adjutant pointed to it. "It seems Analyst Marchais made some headway on the Xarxes Archive while you were filing elsewhere," he noted. "You should consult his notes. They may speed up the final audit." He turned back to his work, signaling the briefing was over.

The Préfecture Communications Officer stepped into the broadcast room, his polished boots clicking on the tile floor. He stopped beside the control panel, his eyes fixed on the technician’s hands. His tone was calm but firm. "Excuse me. That is Préfecture property. What is your authorization for touching it?"

The technician stammered an answer, but the officer just shook his head. He pulled a folded logbook from his jacket pocket. "This is the second time this week someone has altered the signal," he stated, his voice still level but cooler. "The broadcast schedule is a matter of public record. Why must you interfere with the official transmissions?" He waited for a reply, his pen poised over the page to record the violation.

The Préfecture Communications Officer’s voice cut through the low hum of the control room, its tone flat and administrative. He did not approach, but stood framed in the doorway, his gaze fixed on the unauthorized console. "Excuse me. That is Préfecture property," he stated, the words devoid of personal accusation. "What is your authorization?" It was a simple procedural checkpoint, a demand for the paperwork that would resolve the misunderstanding.

When no satisfactory documentation was produced, he advanced into the room, his steps measured. He stopped a precise distance away, folding his arms. "This is the second time this week," he observed, the repetition clearly noted in some internal log. "The broadcast schedule is a matter of public record." A faint, weary exasperation finally colored his neutrality, not directed at the individual but at the persistent disruption to an orderly system. "Why must you interfere?"

The Notariat Archivist was angry. He held up a hand. "Be silent," he said. "You must follow my movements exactly."

He looked at the papers. Then his face changed. He was suddenly very happy. "By the Hexagon, he lives!" he cried. "You say it's Martin... We will see him restored! It is the sworn duty of the Notariat."

He smiled with great relief. "I prayed I had heard correctly. Thank the Republic!" he said. "The Notariat will protect Martin until his papers are in order, have no fear." He made a firm promise. "We will see it done, or be buried in the attempt."

The soldier went to the supply office. The Armurerie Adjutant looked at his sword.

"Ah, a Durendal," the Adjutant said. "Not the usual kind, but it will do. The paperwork is approved!"

Then the Adjutant checked the forms. He got angry. "I would give you a Durendal! But your papers show you have none! Go back and get your armory list right!"

The soldier tried to explain. The Adjutant was still angry. "I said I would give you a Durendal! Your forms show none!"

Suddenly, the Adjutant found the correct form. He became happy. "A Durendal! Excellent! This sword is good for making people follow the rules."

Then his smile faded. "Of course, you need Form 7-B for the Durendal. The regional prefect and the central bureau must both sign it. It is a small rule, but it makes sure everything is done properly."

The armorer’s adjutant looked over the request form, his expression unreadable. "Ah... a Durendal," he said, tapping the paper. "Well. Not the regulation model, but it will suffice. The paperwork is approved!"

He began stamping the form, but then his eyes narrowed. He flipped through the attached inventory sheets, and his neutral look vanished. "I'd requisition a Durendal!" he snapped, his voice rising. "Too bad your forms show none! Return when your armory inventory is properly documented!" He shoved the papers back across the counter.

The adjutant’s anger didn't fade. He pointed a stern finger at the missing section. "I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!" he repeated, making his final point.

Just then, a junior clerk rushed over with a corrected page. The adjutant scanned it, and a wide, approving smile spread across his face. "A Durendal! Excellent!" he boomed, his earlier irritation forgotten. "Good for enforcing compliance with the Hexagon's directives!"

His smile settled into a professional, neutral tone as he pulled out a final document. "Of course, the Durendal’s authorization requires Form 7-B, countersigned by both the regional prefect and the central bureau's liaison," he explained. "A small formality, but one that ensures proper oversight."

The Armurerie Adjutant’s office was a fortress of filing cabinets and triplicate forms. He peered over his spectacles at the requisition slip, his stylus hovering. "Ah... a Durendal. Well." He made a noncommittal notation. "Not the regulation model, but it will suffice. The paperwork is approved!" His tone was one of bureaucratic finality, a transaction concluded within the safe confines of established rules.

The barrier, however, was immediate. When the weapon could not be produced from the armory’s logged inventory, his professional composure fractured. He slapped the flawed form onto the counter. "I'd requisition a Durendal!" he snapped, the offer now a taunt. "Too bad your forms show none! Return when your armory inventory is properly documented!" The repetition was a weapon itself. "I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!" Each word was a hammer blow on the countertop, underscoring the absolute authority of documented proof over stated need.

Then, the missing crate was found, buried under a mislabeled pallet. The Adjutant’s anger evaporated, replaced by a zealous gleam. He ran a hand almost lovingly over the weapon’s housing. "A Durendal! Excellent!" he declared, his earlier obstruction forgotten in the face of a tool that matched his worldview. "Good for enforcing compliance with the Hexagon’s directives!" His satisfaction was palpable, a vision of perfect order now achievable.

The moment of triumph was swiftly enclosed in procedure once more. Setting the Durendal aside, he pulled a fresh, dauntingly complex form from a drawer. "Of course," he said, his voice settling into a flat, instructive monotone, "the Durendal’s authorization requires Form 7-B, countersigned by both the regional prefect and the central bureau’s liaison." He offered a thin, bureaucratic smile. "A small formality, but one that ensures proper oversight." The negotiation was over; the labyrinth of administration stretched on.

The Notariat Official was angry. He glared at the new person. "I do not know why the Préfet likes you," he said. "This office is cursed with you here."

Then another person walked in. The Official's face changed. He smiled a big smile. "Ah, here you are," he said happily. "It is so good to meet you at last."

He was very excited. "You are like a gift from the Marianne herself," he said. "Please, tell me how I can help you."

Finally, he turned back to the first person. His smile was gone. He spoke in a flat voice. "Hello, my Colleague."

The café patron leaned in, his voice low but clear over the clink of cups. "One witness claimed, quote, 'The Republic sent us two agents. And at least one carried a Durendal with a thermal scope.'"

He took a slow sip of his coffee, letting the weight of that statement hang in the air. "It's the exiles, I tell you," he continued, his tone certain. "Devout exiles in Leclercs, searching for a département to administer."

Setting his cup down, he added another piece to the puzzle. "An anonymous adjutant warned that a critical systems failure would be catastrophic. He said the rolling stock is too old and replacement parts are too scarce."

He glanced around before sharing the next bit of news. "Also, Monsieur Giraud is no longer a patron in good standing at the Hôtel de la Paix." He raised an eyebrow meaningfully.

Finally, he finished his report. "In what may be a related development, local apothecaries report a significant decline in their quarterly revenue." He sat back, having dumped all the information he'd gathered, leaving the listener to piece it together.

The Regional Contact leaned close. His voice was quiet. "If the Préfecture asks," he said, "this talk never happened."

He looked down, sad. "But I saw his cellar. It was not full of wine. It was full of files. Each one had a strange name on it."

The Hexagon Enforcer's face turned red. "Are you saying our files are wrong?" he snapped.

Bureaucrat Fournier was angry too. "The Outre-Quartiers can take care of themselves. We have our own files to worry about."

Then Fournier's anger melted away. Fear took its place. His hands shook. "The Chevaliers are coming for my job," he whispered. "I should have known they would send the order."

The Regional Contact leaned close, his voice low. "If the Préfecture asks, this conversation never happened." He looked down, his expression turning sad. "But I was in his cellar last week. I saw the dossiers. Not wine bottles, but files. All labeled with names I didn't recognize."

Across the table, the Hexagon Enforcer’s face hardened with anger. "You thought our paperwork was incomplete? That we missed something?"

Bureaucrat Fournier cut in, his own anger flashing. "The Outre-Quartiers can manage their own affairs. We have our own dossiers to process here." Then he paused, and the anger drained from his face, replaced by fear. He lowered his voice to a whisper. "They're coming for my position. Those Chevaliers. I should have seen the requisition order coming."

The air in the back room of the café was thick with steam and unspoken rules. The Regional Contact leaned across the small, scarred table, his voice dropping to a murmur that was nearly swallowed by the espresso machine’s hiss. "If the Préfecture asks," he stated, the neutrality of his tone a practiced art, "this conversation never happened."

He leaned back, the professional mask slipping for a moment as his gaze grew distant. "But his cellar..." he continued, a note of genuine sorrow threading through the words. "I saw the dossiers. Not wine bottles, but files. All labeled with names I didn't recognize." It was a confession of a violation, a glimpse into a system operating on a parallel track.

The Hexagon Enforcer, a silhouette of tailored severity against the grimy window, didn't move. His voice, when it came, was a blade of controlled anger. "You thought our paperwork was incomplete?" The question wasn't an inquiry; it was an accusation of profound insult, a challenge to the entire architecture of his authority.

Bureaucrat Fournier, who had been nervously turning his cup, found a brittle defiance. "The Outre-Quartiers can manage their own affairs," he asserted, though the anger in his voice was undercut by a tremor. "We have our own dossiers to process." It was the territorial claim of a man guarding a shrinking island.

Suddenly, the anger evaporated, replaced by a cold, spreading dread. Fournier’s eyes widened, fixed on some internal horizon of calamity. "They're coming for my position," he whispered, the fear now raw and personal. "Those Chevaliers. I should have seen the requisition order coming." The abstract jurisdictional confrontation had crystallized into a direct and terrifying threat, aimed squarely at him.

The Concerned Citizen leaned in, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper. "If you haven't found any Syndicalists in your own district," he said with dramatic emphasis, "you're not filing the proper reports!"

He straightened up, his nose twitching as he sniffed the air loudly. "I smell... an unapproved assembly!" he declared, though the street around them was quiet.

His train of thought seemed to jump tracks. "Citizen! Did you know that Syndicalists have a gland that converts red wine into vinegar?" He paused, scratching his chin. "Or, wait... is that the Bretons?"

Finally, he pointed a knowing finger. "If you know what the word 'proletariat' means, do you know what that makes you?" He leaned close again, his eyes wide. "An intellectual... and therefore suspect!"

The Concerned Citizen leaned across the narrow, damp alleyway, his voice dropping to a conspiratorial rasp that carried over the ambient drip of a leaky drainpipe. "If you haven't found any Syndicalists in your own arrondissement," he insisted, his finger tapping the air for emphasis, "you're not filing the proper reports."

He straightened abruptly, his nostrils flaring as he sampled the stagnant air. A series of sharp, wet sniffs punctuated the silence. "I smell..." he declared, eyes narrowing with the certainty of a bloodhound, "...an unapproved assembly!"

His train of thought, however, was a precarious thing, prone to sudden, jarring switches. He blinked, his expression shifting from suspicion to a muddled curiosity. "Citizen! Did you know that Syndicalists have a gland that converts red wine into vinegar?" A flicker of doubt crossed his face. "Or, wait... is that the Bretons?" He dismissed the confusion with a wave, latching onto a more concrete principle.

Leaning in once more, his tone became dangerously instructive. "If you know what the word 'proletariat' means," he said, carefully enunciating each syllable, "do you know what that makes you?" He paused, letting the implication hang in the moist air. "An intellectual," he whispered, the word itself an accusation. "And therefore suspect!"

The Regional Contact gave a single, curt nod, the gesture swallowed by the low murmur of the cafe. "Understood." He turned and melted into the flow of pedestrians along the boulevard, his role in the exchange complete.

At a nearby table, a man in a well-worn coat caught the eye of another. He offered the subtle, palm-out gesture common in their arrondissement. "Greetings, fellow Parisian."

The returned nod was weary. The second man, a Gallian citizen by his accent, stared into the dregs of his espresso. His initial formality dissolved into a hollow confession. "I've just come from the archives," he began, the words heavy. "They've misplaced the entire Third Republic's civic works registry. A century of documentation, gone." He said it with the quiet devastation of a historian witnessing a silent fire, the loss not of objects, but of memory itself.

Their conversation drew the attention of an older woman at the adjacent table, Archivist Durand, who had been pretending to read a journal. She cleared her throat, interjecting with academic detachment. "A significant loss. Yet it underscores a point of methodology." She tapped a finger beside a sketched menhir in her notes. "The primary objection to a First Republic dating for these stones is that they bear no resemblance whatsoever to any other documented First Republic civic works." Her tone was neutral, a recitation of fact, creating a barrier of pure scholarship against the wave of the citizen's personal dismay.

The Préfecture Adjutant stood in the dusty yard, his uniform crisp against the rough surroundings. His tone was calm, almost conversational. "There's no point filing official forms for someone who won't read them," he said. "I took the risk of coming here myself, same as you took a risk by staying. We'll just have to see what this situation yields."

He watched for a reaction, but when none came, he continued in the same steady voice. "You can't stamp sense into a man who refuses the ink." He nodded toward the road, where the silhouette of a Leclerc tank was just visible, its engine idling. "I brought that as my alternative argument. If that's the language you understand, then your future and your papers belong East of the Rhine."

The Préfecture Adjutant leaned against the splintered doorframe, his gaze sweeping the sparse room before settling on the man opposite him. He spoke with a tone of pragmatic finality, as if closing a ledger. "No point filing forms for someone who won't read them." He shifted his weight, a faint creak of leather accompanying the motion. "I took the risk of coming here, same as you. We'll see what the terroir yields." The metaphor hung in the air, an abstract suggestion that the land itself would soon render its verdict on their standoff.

He pushed off from the frame, his posture straightening into an official rigidity. "You can't stamp sense into a man who refuses the ink." His voice remained level, devoid of heat but full of implication. He gestured with a slight tilt of his head toward the window, where the silhouette of the heavy Leclerc armored vehicle was just visible in the dusty street. "I came with the Leclerc idling outside—if that's the language you understand, then your papers belong East of the Rhine." It was not a shout, but a cold recalibration of the conversation’s currency, moving from words to a tangible, metallic show of force. The barrier between them was no longer just ideological; it had materialized in steel and diesel outside the door.

The Audition Clerk smiled at the first person. "Welcome, Alsatian, to the Trial of Ten Seals," he said. He pointed to the right. "Through each of nine doors, another person waits for you to challenge them."

He turned to the next person. His smile was still warm. "Welcome, Corsican, to the Trial of Ten Seals," he said. Again, he pointed. "To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge."

Finally, he greeted the last person. He was happy to see them all. "Welcome, Savoyard, to the Trial of Ten Seals," he said. He gave the same instructions. "To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge."

The Audition Clerk stood before a long, stone corridor lined with nine heavy doors. He wore a bright, welcoming smile as the first Candidate stepped forward.

"Welcome, Alsatian, to the Trial of Ten Seals," the Clerk announced, his voice cheerful. He gestured to the right. "To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge."

A second figure approached. The Clerk's smile didn't waver, and he repeated the greeting with the same friendly tone. "Welcome, Corsican, to the Trial of Ten Seals. To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge."

Finally, a third Candidate arrived. The Clerk gave a welcoming nod, his happiness undimmed by the repetition. "Welcome, Savoyard, to the Trial of Ten Seals," he said warmly. "To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge." He then stepped aside, letting each of them see the long hallway of sealed doors that blocked their path.

The Audition Clerk stood before the first of the heavy oak doors, a parchment scroll unfurled in his hands. His expression was one of genuine, almost ceremonial, welcome. "Welcome, Alsatian, to the Trial of Ten Seals," he announced, his voice resonating in the stone antechamber. He gestured with a fluid motion to his right, where a corridor of identical doors receded into shadow. "To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge."

He moved with practiced grace to the next threshold, the same scroll now feeling like a prop in a well-rehearsed play. The smile never wavered, but it took on a polished, institutional quality. "Welcome, Corsican, to the Trial of Ten Seals." His gesture was identical, a sweeping arc that encompassed the daunting gauntlet. "To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge."

Arriving at the third door, his performance achieved a state of serene automation. The words were not merely spoken; they were bestowed, like a uniform handed to a new recruit. "Welcome, Savoyard, to the Trial of Ten Seals." His eyes held a glint of impersonal encouragement, a gatekeeper dispensing the same crucial, limiting information to each aspirant in turn. "To your right, through each of nine doors, another Candidate awaits your challenge." The repetition itself was the first lesson of the trial: you are one of many, and the path is identical for all.

The Préfecture Official shuffled through the file on his desk. He recognized the name and the case number. His tone was matter-of-fact as he looked up. "We've processed you before," he stated. It wasn't a question, just a simple record of fact.

He closed the folder and slid it to the side, his expression still neutral. He needed to be clear about who he was addressing. He added the single, formal title. "Doctor."

The Préfecture Official’s pen scratched across the form, a sound as familiar and impersonal as the ticking of the wall clock. He didn’t glance up as he spoke, his tone flat with administrative routine. "We've processed you before." It was a statement of fact, devoid of accusation or warmth, simply an acknowledgment of a prior entry in the system.

He finally lifted his gaze, his eyes scanning the applicant’s file before settling on the title noted there. The ambient chatter from the other clerks and petitioners in the hall seemed to recede, leaving only the weight of the pending judgment in the small space between them. "Doctor." The word was delivered with the same procedural neutrality, yet it carried an implicit demand for the credentials and compliance the title was supposed to guarantee.

The Bureau Chief leaned back in his leather chair, the only sound the soft hum of the office air system. He studied the agent standing before him, his tone measured and clear.

“Should you choose to pursue this,” he said, “I would expect your sole objective to be its delivery here. To this office.”

He waited a moment, letting the instruction settle. Then he leaned forward, resting his elbows on the polished desk.

“Are we understood?” he continued, his voice still neutral but firm. “Disregard her requisition. Proceed directly to the location she indicated, and return with the dossier. Nothing else.” He held the agent’s gaze. “This task transcends any departmental dispute. It is now your only priority.”

The Préfecture Intervenor looked down at the thick file in his hands, his expression weary. His voice was quiet but firm. "My planning is simply more thorough than yours," he explained. "It is all a matter of proper documentation, you see. Every rule must be followed."

He closed the folder slowly, then looked up, his eyes full of a tired regret. "Please," he said softly, holding up a hand. "Do not interpret this as a personal failing. The system is very strict."

The Préfecture Intervenor’s gaze drifted from the file in his hands to the window, where a grey afternoon light did little to illuminate the cramped office. His voice, when it came, was a soft, deliberate monotone. "My strategic planning is simply more thorough." He tapped a finger on the dense stack of papers before him, each page a testament to a process that had grown beyond its original intent. "It's a matter of proper documentation, you see." The statement hung in the air, not as a boast, but as a lament for a system that valued ledgers over lives.

He watched the other person absorb the finality of it, the way their shoulders settled into a posture of defeat he had witnessed too many times. A faint, weary sigh escaped him. "Please," he said, the word carrying the weight of an apology he was not permitted to formally give, "do not interpret this as a personal failing." His eyes held a genuine, profound sorrow, acknowledging the cruel irony that the most meticulous interventions often produced the deepest, most personal wounds.

The Préfecture Official, who was also the Claimant Brother, jolted awake in his chair. He blinked at the familiar office walls. "What? Who...?" he muttered, rubbing his face. "Damn, not this dream again. Wake up! Wake up!!"

But the memory from the dream wouldn't fade. His voice grew quiet and heavy. "But his cellar... I saw the dossiers. Not wine bottles, but files. All labeled with names I didn't recognize."

He was so lost in the troubling memory that he didn't notice the door open. A Préfecture Agent stood there, her lip curled in disgust. "Did you not hear my approach?" she said, her tone icy. "Now I must file a report of resistance. How tedious."

She pulled a tablet from her jacket and began tapping on the screen with sharp, annoyed strokes. Without looking up, she added, "Another incident requiring documentation."

Adjoint Lefèvre leaned against the gatepost, a faint smile on his face. "My opinion?" he said, his tone almost happy. "What this section needs is a bit more basic human decency. A shared meal, perhaps. It would do everyone good."

But his smile faded quickly, replaced by a look of worry. "The camaraderie helps," he admitted, his voice dropping. "But we still have the explosive ordnance inspection to pass. That's the real test."

The Gendarme standing guard nodded slowly, his own expression turning grim with fear. "Be wary of the hounds during that inspection," he warned. "They're trained to ignore the paperwork and sniff out what's hidden."

Then the Gendarme’s face went neutral, his eyes thoughtful as he recalled something. "Speaking of hidden things," he said. "I've heard the archives mention a sealed repository somewhere in this arrondissement. A 'Silo'. Might be worth knowing about."

Adjoint Lefèvre leaned back in his chair, a flicker of genuine warmth softening his usually officious demeanor. "My opinion?" he began, the question hanging in the dusty air of the inspection office. "What this section needs is a bit more basic human decency. A shared meal, perhaps." He envisioned, for a moment, the barrier of rank dissolving over bread and wine.

The vision evaporated as quickly as it had come. His expression tightened, the earlier happiness leaching away into a palpable anxiety. "The camaraderie helps," he conceded, his voice dropping, "but we still have the explosive ordnance inspection to pass." The unspoken consequences of failure hummed in the silence between the words.

The Gendarme, who had been listening with the detached focus of a predator, shifted his weight. His own features mirrored the Adjutant’s fear, but his was colder, more specific. "Be wary of the hounds," he said, the warning cutting through the Adjutant’s broader dread. "They're trained to ignore the paperwork." It was a reminder that their negotiation with the inspectors would mean nothing to creatures operating on pure instinct.

Then, as if filing the shared fear away, the Gendarme’s tone flattened into something clinical and detached. He tapped a finger on the district warning order. "I've heard the archives mention a sealed repository somewhere in this arrondissement." He met Lefèvre’s eyes, the negotiation pivoting from survival to strategy. "A 'Silo'."

The Chef de Bureau was smiling. "I heard your paperwork made this happen," he said to Duval. "The whole Notariat thanks you!"

Then he looked surprised. "I am promoting you," he said. "You are now an Agent de Terrain. You may use Lucienne of the 7th as your helper. Congratulations."

Suddenly, his face turned mean. "The Notariat takes back its protection," he said. "You have a debt to pay. Get out of my office now."

Duval did not argue. He said, "Goodbye."

He walked out into the hall. He sighed. "Back to the forms for poor old Duval," he said to himself.

The Chef de Bureau beamed, clapping his hands together. "I heard it was your paperwork that made it all possible," he said. "The entire Notariat is grateful!"

Then his expression changed to one of pleasant shock. "In fact, I am promoting you," he announced. "You are now an Agent de Terrain. This means you may use Lucienne of the 7th Arrondissement as your approved liaison. Congratulations on your new grade."

But the warmth vanished from his face, replaced by cold disgust. "However, the Notariat withdraws its protection until the procedural debt is settled," he stated, his voice turning sharp. "Until then, get out of my office."

Sous-Préfet Duval simply nodded. "Au revoir," he said, his tone flat and neutral. He turned and walked into the hallway, where the low hum of ambient chatter from other offices filled the air. He sighed to himself. "Back to the forms for poor old Duval."

The air in the Chef de Bureau’s office, usually thick with the scent of dust and ink, felt momentarily light. The Chef leaned forward, a genuine smile softening his officious demeanor. "I heard it was your paperwork that made it all possible," he said, his voice carrying a warmth Duval hadn't heard in years. "The entire Notariat is grateful!"

Before Duval could formulate a modest reply, the Chef’s expression shifted into one of theatrical surprise, as if he himself were just hearing the news. "In fact," he announced, producing a dossier stamped with a crimson seal, "I am promoting you to Agent de Terrain." He let the title hang in the air, a tangible reward. "It means you may use Lucienne of the 7th Arrondissement as your approved liaison. Congratulations on your new grade."

The moment of triumph was brittle, shattered by the Chef’s next utterance. His face contorted, not with anger, but with a profound and personal disgust, as if Duval had revealed a rotting core. "However," he spat, the word a legal scalpel, "the Notariat withdraws its protection until the procedural debt is settled." He waved a dismissive hand toward the door, the ambient chatter from the corridor now sounding like a distant judgment. "Until then, get out of my office."

Duval absorbed the reversal without a flinch. The bureaucratic machinery had simply shifted gears. He gave a shallow, perfectly correct nod. "Au revoir," he said, his tone devoid of anything but acknowledgment. As he turned to leave, he murmured to the empty air, a dry epitaph for his brief elevation, "Back to the forms for poor old Duval." The threat of the countdown had not been lifted, merely transferred from a shared burden to a personal ledger, its ticking now the only sound following him into the hall.

The Armurerie Adjutant was angry. He pointed at the papers. "I need a Durendal sword!" he said. "But your forms say you have none. Go back and fix your inventory forms!"

He was still upset. "I would take a Durendal! Your forms show none!" he repeated.

The Gallian citizen felt sad. He looked at the wrong forms. "But the papers are wrong," he said softly. "What can I do?" He took a deep breath.

He decided to feel better. "I won't let paperwork ruin my day," he said. "The sun is shining."

Just then, another person walked up. It was a Gallian citizen. He gave a friendly nod. "Greetings, fellow Parisian," he said.

The Armurerie Adjutant’s voice cut through the administrative murmur of the requisitions hall, sharp with bureaucratic impatience. "I'd requisition a Durendal!" he declared, slapping the citizen’s paperwork with the back of his fingers. "Too bad your forms show none! Return when your armory inventory is properly documented!" His posture was rigid, a monument to procedural infallibility.

When the Gallian citizen began to protest, the Adjutant repeated the verdict like a hammer driving a nail. "I'd requisition a Durendal! Too bad your forms show none!" This time, his tone carried a finality that extinguished any hope of appeal. The citizen’s shoulders slumped, the initial spark of anger dissolving into the cold reality of the triplicate forms before him.

"But what can one do?" the citizen murmured, more to himself than to the official. A wave of resignation washed over his features, the frustration transmuting into melancholy. "The forms are what they are." He gathered the rejected documents, the rustle of paper sounding like a sigh. "A deep breath, then."

The Adjutant watched the man’s retreat, his own rigid anger softening into something more contemplative. He straightened a stack of permits on his desk, a small ritual of order. "One must not let the paperwork spoil the afternoon," he said, almost to himself. His gaze drifted to the high window where a shaft of dusty sunlight fell across the stone floor. "The sun is out, after all."

Stepping out into the cobbled courtyard, the Gallian citizen paused, allowing the warmth to displace the chill of the office. He noticed another figure lingering nearby and offered a weary, conciliatory nod. "Greetings, fellow Parisian." The salutation was a simple reconnection to the world beyond the ledger, an acknowledgment of shared space, if not shared fortune.
